name: Mango Smoothie
short: Thick & creamy mango smoothie
description: A refreshing blend of ripe mangoes, yogurt, and honey creating a thick, creamy smoothie that's perfect for any time of the day. Made with the finest Alphonso mangoes.
history: Indian mango drinks have been a part of summer culture for centuries. The mango smoothie tradition evolved from the classic mango lassi, combining Western smoothie techniques with traditional Indian flavors.
ingredients: Ripe mango pulp, yogurt, honey/sugar, ice
preparation: Fresh mango pulp is blended with creamy yogurt and a touch of honey until smooth and creamy. Ice is added for the perfect consistency.
serving: Served in a tall chilled glass with a sprig of fresh mint leaves on top for garnish
nutrition: Rich in vitamins A and C, probiotics from yogurt, natural sugars for quick energy. A healthy and refreshing beverage.
trivia: Alphonso mango, known as the 'King of Mangoes', is commonly used in premium smoothies for its superior taste and aroma

name: Paneer Tikka
short: Grilled cottage cheese skewers
description: Marinated cottage cheese cubes grilled to perfection with bell peppers and onions, served with mint chutney. A signature North Indian starter.
history: Paneer Tikka has its roots in tandoori cuisine from the Punjab region. It became popular as the vegetarian alternative to Chicken Tikka and is now served in restaurants worldwide.
ingredients: Paneer (cottage cheese), yogurt, aromatic spices, bell peppers, onions
preparation: Paneer cubes are marinated in a spiced yogurt mixture for several hours, then skewered with vegetables and grilled in a tandoor or oven until golden and smoky.
serving: Served hot on skewers with mint chutney and sliced onions on the side
nutrition: High in protein and calcium from paneer, rich in antioxidants from spices
trivia: This is the signature North Indian starter found in every restaurant menu globally

name: Grilled Salmon
short: Atlantic salmon with herbs
description: Fresh Atlantic salmon fillet grilled to perfection with aromatic herbs, garlic, and a hint of lemon. Served with seasonal sautéed vegetables.
history: Grilled salmon is a popular Western seafood dish with Nordic and European origins. Salmon has been prized for thousands of years for its rich flavor and nutritional benefits.
ingredients: Atlantic salmon fillet, fresh herbs (dill, parsley), garlic, lemon, olive oil
preparation: Fresh salmon fillet is seasoned with herbs and garlic, then pan-grilled or oven-baked until the outside is crispy and the inside remains tender and flaky.
serving: Served with sautéed seasonal vegetables and fresh lemon wedges on the side
nutrition: Excellent source of omega-3 fatty acids, lean protein, vitamin D, and B vitamins
trivia: Salmon is considered one of the healthiest fish with Nordic and European origins dating back centuries

name: Chocolate Lava Cake
short: Warm molten chocolate center
description: Decadent chocolate cake with a molten chocolate center that flows out when cut. Served warm with a scoop of vanilla ice cream.
history: The Chocolate Lava Cake, also known as Molten Chocolate Cake, was invented by French chef Michel Bras in 1981. It became a restaurant sensation in the 1990s.
ingredients: Dark chocolate, butter, eggs, flour, sugar, vanilla extract
preparation: The cake batter is baked at high temperature for a precise time using the half-baked center method, creating a firm exterior with a liquid chocolate center.
serving: Served warm, dusted with powdered sugar, with vanilla ice cream pairing on the side
nutrition: Rich in sugar and fats, provides quick energy. An indulgent dessert treat.
trivia: Also called 'Molten Lava Cake' because the flowing chocolate center resembles molten lava

name: Butter Chicken
short: Creamy tomato curry with tender chicken
description: Succulent pieces of tandoori chicken simmered in a rich, creamy tomato-based gravy with aromatic spices and butter. A North Indian classic.
history: Butter Chicken was invented at Moti Mahal restaurant in Delhi by Kundan Lal Gujral in the 1950s. It was created as a way to use leftover tandoori chicken.
ingredients: Tandoori chicken pieces, tomatoes, cream, butter, Kashmiri red chili, garam masala, kasuri methi (dried fenugreek leaves)
preparation: Chicken is first roasted in a tandoor, then cooked in a rich buttery tomato gravy with cream and aromatic spices
serving: Best served with naan bread, kulcha, or jeera rice
nutrition: High in protein from chicken, rich in calories from cream and butter. A hearty, satisfying meal.
trivia: Invented at the legendary Moti Mahal restaurant in Delhi, now famous worldwide

name: Masala Dosa
short: Crispy rice crepe with spiced potato filling
description: Thin, crispy fermented rice and lentil crepe filled with spiced potato masala. A South Indian breakfast staple enjoyed worldwide.
history: Masala Dosa is a traditional South Indian food that originated in Udupi, Karnataka. Udupi restaurants popularized it across India and internationally.
ingredients: Fermented rice and urad dal batter, potatoes, onions, mustard seeds, curry leaves, turmeric, spices
preparation: Fermented batter is spread thin on a hot griddle to create a crispy dosa. Spiced potato filling is placed inside and folded.
serving: Served hot with sambar (lentil soup) and coconut chutney on the side
nutrition: Fermented batter aids digestion, light on stomach, rich in carbohydrates. A healthy breakfast option.
trivia: Udupi restaurants made this dish famous and it's now one of India's most iconic foods

name: Masala Chai
short: Indian spiced tea with aromatic spices
description: Traditional Indian tea brewed with black tea leaves, milk, sugar, and aromatic spices like cardamom, ginger, and cloves. A daily ritual for millions.
history: Masala Chai became integral to Indian tea culture after British colonial influence. The tradition of adding spices has ancient Ayurvedic roots. Roadside tea stalls made it a cultural phenomenon.
ingredients: Black tea leaves, milk, fresh ginger, cardamom, cloves, black pepper, sugar
preparation: Spices are first boiled in water to extract flavors, then tea leaves and milk are added and simmered until perfectly brewed
serving: Traditionally served in small glasses with biscuits on the side
nutrition: Contains caffeine for alertness, antioxidants from tea, warming spices aid digestion
trivia: Known as 'cutting chai' in Mumbai when served in half glasses at roadside stalls

name: Chicken Biryani
short: Aromatic basmati rice with spiced chicken
description: Fragrant basmati rice layered with marinated chicken, caramelized onions, saffron, and aromatic spices. Slow-cooked to perfection.
history: Biryani has Mughlai and Persian origins, brought to India by Mughal rulers. It evolved into various regional styles, with Hyderabadi and Lucknowi biryani being the most famous.
ingredients: Basmati rice, chicken, yogurt, fried onions, saffron, biryani spices (cardamom, cinnamon, bay leaves), ghee
preparation: Rice and marinated chicken are layered and cooked using the dum method (slow cooking in a sealed pot) to create perfectly aromatic biryani
serving: Served hot with raita (yogurt dip), boiled egg, and salan (gravy)
nutrition: Balanced meal with carbohydrates from rice and protein from chicken. Rich in spices with health benefits.
trivia: Multiple regional styles exist including Hyderabadi, Lucknowi, Kolkata, and Malabar biryani

name: Gulab Jamun
short: Soft milk dumplings in rose-scented syrup
description: Soft, spongy milk-solid dumplings deep-fried and soaked in aromatic rose-cardamom sugar syrup. A festive Indian sweet.
history: Gulab Jamun is a festive Indian sweet with Persian origins, brought to India during the Mughal era. Common at weddings and celebrations.
ingredients: Khoya (milk solids), milk powder, all-purpose flour, sugar syrup infused with rose water and cardamom
preparation: Milk solids are shaped into balls, deep-fried until golden, then immediately soaked in warm rose-cardamom sugar syrup
serving: Served warm or at room temperature, often garnished with chopped pistachios
nutrition: High in sugar and dairy content. An indulgent dessert.
trivia: Common at Indian weddings and festivals. The name comes from 'gulab' (rose water) and 'jamun' (a berry it resembles)

name: Mango Lassi
short: Thick & creamy mango yogurt drink
description: Thick, creamy smoothie made with fresh mangoes, yogurt, and a touch of sugar. Perfectly refreshing and nutritious.
history: Lassi is a North Indian yogurt drink with roots in Punjab. It has been consumed for thousands of years. Mango lassi became famous in the 1960s.
ingredients: Fresh mango pulp, yogurt, sugar or honey, cardamom powder
preparation: Fresh mango pulp, yogurt, and sugar are blended together until smooth and creamy
serving: Served in a chilled glass, often garnished with a mint leaf or mango slice
nutrition: Rich in probiotics from yogurt, vitamins from mangoes, aids digestion
trivia: Famous in Punjab and now enjoyed worldwide as a refreshing summer beverage

name: Paneer Tikka Masala
short: Grilled cottage cheese in rich gravy
description: Char-grilled paneer cubes cooked in a creamy tomato-onion gravy with bell peppers, aromatic spices and fresh cream. A vegetarian delight.
history: Paneer Tikka Masala was inspired by the famous Chicken Tikka Masala and is now a global favorite in Indian restaurants as a vegetarian option.
ingredients: Paneer (cottage cheese), tomato-onion gravy, cream, bell peppers, aromatic spices
preparation: Paneer tikka is first grilled until charred, then added to a rich tomato-cream gravy and simmered
serving: Best enjoyed with naan bread or roti
nutrition: Rich and creamy, high in protein and calcium from paneer
trivia: A global favorite vegetarian dish inspired by Chicken Tikka Masala

name: Samosa
short: Crispy fried pastry with spiced potato filling
description: Golden-fried triangular pastries stuffed with spiced potatoes and peas. Served hot with tamarind and mint chutney.
history: Samosas have Persian origins but became an integral part of Indian street food culture. Now one of India's most iconic snacks.
ingredients: All-purpose flour shell, spiced potato and green pea filling, cumin, coriander, garam masala
preparation: Spiced potato filling is wrapped in flour dough, shaped into triangles, and deep-fried until golden and crispy
serving: Served hot with mint chutney and tamarind chutney
nutrition: Fried and carb-heavy, best enjoyed as an occasional snack
trivia: One of India's most iconic street food snacks, enjoyed across the country

name: Paneer Tikka
short: Grilled cottage cheese skewers
description: Marinated cottage cheese cubes grilled to perfection with bell peppers and onions, served with mint chutney. A signature North Indian starter.
history: Paneer Tikka has its roots in tandoori cuisine from the Punjab region. It became popular as the vegetarian alternative to Chicken Tikka.
ingredients: Paneer (cottage cheese), yogurt, aromatic spices, bell peppers, onions
preparation: Paneer cubes are marinated in spiced yogurt mixture, then skewered with vegetables and grilled until golden
serving: Served hot on skewers with mint chutney and sliced onions
nutrition: High in protein and calcium from paneer, rich in antioxidants from spices
trivia: This is the signature North Indian starter found in every restaurant menu globally

name: Jalebi
short: Crispy sweet spirals in sugar syrup
description: Crispy, deep-fried flour spirals soaked in saffron-infused sugar syrup. Best enjoyed hot and fresh.
history: Jalebi is an ancient Indian sweet with origins tracing back centuries. It's a common breakfast sweet in North India.
ingredients: Fermented all-purpose flour batter, sugar syrup, saffron, cardamom
preparation: Fermented batter is piped in spiral shapes into hot oil, deep-fried until crispy, then immediately dipped in sugar syrup
serving: Served hot, often paired with rabri (thickened sweetened milk) or enjoyed on its own
nutrition: Very high in sugar content, an indulgent sweet treat
trivia: A common breakfast sweet in North India, often enjoyed with milk or rabri

name: Chole Bhature
short: Spicy chickpea curry with fluffy fried bread
description: Tangy and spicy chickpea curry served with large, fluffy deep-fried bread. A hearty North Indian breakfast favorite.
history: Chole Bhature is a Punjabi and North Indian food specialty, now a popular breakfast and street food across North India, especially famous in Delhi.
ingredients: Chickpeas cooked with spices (chole masala), all-purpose flour for bhature, yogurt, onions, tomatoes
preparation: Chickpeas are slow-cooked with aromatic spices. Bhature dough is rolled out and deep-fried until puffed and golden
serving: Served hot with pickled onions, green chilies, and a side of lassi
nutrition: High in carbohydrates and protein from chickpeas. A filling meal.
trivia: Delhi's favorite breakfast and one of the most popular street foods in North India

name: Kheer (Rice Pudding)
short: Creamy rice pudding with cardamom & nuts
description: Slow-cooked rice pudding made with milk, sugar, cardamom, and garnished with almonds, pistachios, and saffron strands.
history: Kheer is one of India's oldest desserts, mentioned in ancient texts. It's a temple and festive dessert traditionally prepared during special occasions.
ingredients: Basmati rice, full-cream milk, sugar, cardamom powder, saffron strands, chopped nuts (almonds, pistachios, cashews)
preparation: Rice is slow-simmered in milk until creamy, sweetened with sugar, flavored with cardamom, and garnished with nuts and saffron
serving: Can be served chilled or warm, garnished with nuts and saffron strands
nutrition: Rich in carbohydrates and calcium from milk. A nourishing dessert.
trivia: Also known as 'Payesh' in Bengal and 'Payasam' in South India with regional variations

name: Fresh Sugarcane Juice
short: Freshly extracted pure sugarcane juice
description: Freshly pressed sugarcane juice with a squeeze of lime and ginger. Naturally sweet and incredibly refreshing.
history: Sugarcane juice is a common Indian summer drink that has been consumed since ancient times. Very popular in hot climates across India.
ingredients: Fresh sugarcane stalks, ginger (optional), lemon juice, ice
preparation: Fresh sugarcane is passed through a mechanical juice extractor, then served with ginger and lemon
serving: Served chilled over ice in tall glasses
nutrition: Rich in natural sugars for instant energy, contains minerals like calcium, magnesium, and iron
trivia: A staple summer drink across India, very popular in hot climates for instant refreshment

name: Dal Makhani
short: Creamy black lentils slow-cooked overnight
description: Slow-cooked black lentils and kidney beans in a rich, creamy tomato-based gravy with butter and cream. A Punjabi delicacy.
history: Dal Makhani originated from Punjabi dhaba slow-cook traditions and was popularized by restaurants. Traditionally slow-cooked overnight for maximum flavor.
ingredients: Black lentils (urad dal), kidney beans (rajma), butter, cream, tomatoes, ginger-garlic paste, aromatic spices
preparation: Lentils are soaked and then slow-simmered for hours with butter, cream, and spices until creamy and rich
serving: Best served with naan bread, roti, or steamed basmati rice
nutrition: High in protein from lentils, rich in fats from butter and cream
trivia: Considered the 'King of Dals' in North Indian cuisine due to its rich, indulgent flavor

name: Rasgulla
short: Spongy cottage cheese balls in sugar syrup
description: Light, spongy cottage cheese balls cooked in light sugar syrup. A Bengali delicacy that's refreshingly sweet.
history: Rasgulla is a Bengal and Odisha sweet. It was popularized by Bengali confectioner Nobin Chandra Das in the 19th century. There's a GI tag dispute between the two states.
ingredients: Chhena (fresh cottage cheese made from milk), sugar syrup, cardamom, rose water
preparation: Fresh chhena is kneaded and shaped into balls, then boiled in sugar syrup until they become spongy and absorb the syrup
serving: Served chilled in the sugar syrup
nutrition: Moderate protein from cottage cheese, high sugar content
trivia: Famous GI tag dispute between Bengal and Odisha over its origin

name: Nimbu Pani (Lemonade)
short: Refreshing Indian-style lemonade
description: Freshly squeezed lemon juice with water, sugar, salt, and a hint of cumin. A perfect summer cooler.
history: Nimbu Pani is India's traditional summer drink and thirst quencher, consumed for centuries. Known for its perfect balance of sweet, salty, and tangy flavors.
ingredients: Fresh lemon juice, water, sugar, salt, roasted cumin powder, black salt, ice
preparation: Fresh lemon juice is mixed with water, sugar, and salt, then flavored with cumin and chilled
serving: Served over ice cubes with fresh mint leaves as garnish
nutrition: Rich in vitamin C, low in calories, helps with hydration
trivia: Also known as 'Shikanji' in some regions of North India

name: Vada Pav
short: Mumbai's famous potato fritter burger
description: Spicy mashed potato fritter sandwiched in a soft pav (bun) with chutneys and fried green chilies. Mumbai's iconic street food.
history: Vada Pav was invented in 1966 by Ashok Vaidya near Dadar station in Mumbai. It's now synonymous with Mumbai street food culture.
ingredients: Spiced potato patty (batata vada), pav bread, green chutney, tamarind chutney, garlic chutney, fried green chilies
preparation: Spiced mashed potato is coated in gram flour batter and deep-fried. The vada is then placed inside a pav with chutneys
serving: Served hot with fried green chilies on the side
nutrition: High in carbohydrates, fried snack. Best enjoyed occasionally.
trivia: Called the 'Indian burger' and is Mumbai's most iconic street food

name: Idli Sambhar
short: Steamed rice cakes with lentil soup
description: Soft, fluffy steamed rice cakes served with aromatic lentil-vegetable soup and coconut chutney. A South Indian staple.
history: Idli is a South Indian staple and ancient dish mentioned in texts dating back to 920 CE. It's known for being light, healthy, and nutritious.
ingredients: Fermented rice and urad dal batter for idlis, toor dal (lentils), mixed vegetables, tamarind, sambar spices
preparation: Fermented batter is steamed in special idli molds. Sambar is prepared by simmering lentils with vegetables and spices
serving: Served hot with sambar and coconut chutney
nutrition: Light and fermented, low in fat, easy to digest. One of India's healthiest breakfast options.
trivia: Considered one of India's healthiest breakfast foods due to fermentation and steaming process
